awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A low cost, label-free, multiplexable optical cavity biosensor with high sensitivity, high selectivity, and a large dynamic range using chained differential detection
awd_abstract_narration:
1350648 - Kim

Technical Abstract

The early detection of diseases is the key to improving survival rates of patients and reducing economic impacts. Point of care diagnosis is the time critical solution for the early detection of diseases accomplished by staging effective diagnosis tools near the patient, either at the patient?s bedside or at a physician?s office, to monitor and diagnose the patient?s health and wellness without the costly and time-consuming processes necessary when using centralized laboratories. The objective of this proposed research is to develop a novel optical cavity biosensor using chained differential detection for the purpose of point of care diagnosis. Optical cavity based biosensors are by nature very promising for point of care diagnosis due to their label-free operation, low cost, high sensitivity, and high selectivity. On top of the intrinsic benefits of optical cavity based biosensors, the team introduces (1) a three laser diode system to accomplish multiplexability, (2) a differential detection method to enhance its sensitivity, (3) a chained mechanism to increase the linear dynamic range significantly, and (4) a simple cavity structure which is easy to integrate with a sample handling system such as microfluidics. Successful completion of the proposed research project will result in a promising platform for a point of care biosensor that can be used for early detection of diseases and possibly create a new paradigm of medical diagnosis.

For general public:

The goal of this research is to develop a low cost and highly sensitive device which will test for multiple diseases using a small amount of a biological sample, usually blood. The design is composed of a biosensor with simple two reflecting mirror structure (optical resonance cavity), constructed using well known fabrication processes. The simple design of the device ensures that it will be low cost, thus making it accessible to patients in both developed and developing countries. Since the early detection of diseases is the key to treating them effectively, it is crucial for patients to be tested regularly. This device will enable tests to be conducted by the patient in the home or at a physician?s office, in lieu of extensive and time consuming tests, allowing the patient to regularly monitor for the presence of multiple diseases. Enabling the patient to test his/herself regularly will allow diseases to be discovered early and allow for more effective and less expensive treatments.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we developed a biosensor for an early detection of various diseases at the patient’s bedside or at a physician’s office using an optical cavity structure. The biosensor is designed to detect certain biomolecules in bodily fluids which can be used as indicators of diseases. For a biosensor to be used near the patients, the biosensor must be (1) low-cost so that an individual or a clinic can afford it, (2) highly sensitive to accurately detect diseases, (3) highly specific to detect only target molecules, (4) easy-to-use without complex procedures and multiple chemicals, and (5) portable to be able to conduct molecular detection without other external instruments. The biosensor satisfying all these characteristics is called a point-of-care (POC) biosensor.

Our optical cavity-based biosensor (OCB) system employs low-cost components while achieving a high sensitivity by engineering the optical cavity structure. The optical cavity structure is a simple structure created by two partially reflective mirrors with a small gap in between. We optimized this structure so that measured optical power values of two laser beams with different wavelengths are changing in opposite directions as the refractive index of the fluid changes or target biomolecules attaches on receptor molecules inside the cavity. Then, we applied a differential detection method to increase the sensitivity. Using the specific relationship between a target molecule and its receptor molecule such as an antibody and an antigen, the OCB system is designed to detect only specific molecules. It does not require any extra molecular process called ‘labeling’ (i.e., the OCB system is a label-free system) and, therefore, it is easy to use. The OCB system can be integrated into a portable system to be a true POC biosensor.

Through the support of this grant, we were able to design the optical cavity structure, fabricate the designed optical cavity samples, build the optical detection system on an optics table, develop surface treatment processes to prepare the sensing surface to detect only specific target molecules, and conduct experiments to demonstrate its detection capability using (1) refractive index fluids, (2) biotinylated Bovine Serum Albumin (BSA) with streptavidin-coated surface, (3) streptavidin with biotin-coated surface, and also (4) C-reactive protein (CRP) with its antibody-coated surface. Streptavidin-biotin conjugate has been used as a model system for demonstrating the capability of new bio-detection approach. We were able to show that the estimated minimum detectable concentration of streptavidin with our new low-cost POC system is comparable to that of other state-of-the-art biosensing systems. CRP has been used as an indicator of acute inflammatory response. We also demonstrated that the minimum detectable concentration of CRP can be comparable to other state-of-the-art biosensing systems. Due to the highly sensitive resonant nature of the optical cavity to its cavity width, it was very challenging to fabricate optical cavity samples repeatably and reliably. The fabrication tolerance of the cavity width is extremely tight. To mitigate this problem, we proposed and demonstrated a three-laser system employing a chaining mechanism to significantly improve the dynamic range and fabrication tolerance. The polymer swelling property is later employed to produce optical cavity sample reliably with a high success rate of fabricating measurable samples (>90%). We also investigated further to enhance the sensitivity by modifying the differential calculation equation.

A total of 12 undergraduate students (8 minority students) were selected as summer undergraduate researchers and supported by this grant. This grant also supported 8 local high school students (5 minority students) during the grant period to participate in the research activities. Upon the completion of the summer research program, those high school students gave presentations to their peers and teachers about the project and their research experiences. A total of 9 unique students were supported in part by this grant for their master’s and PhD training. A capstone senior design project was developed based on this research project. A total of 35 undergraduate engineering students (14 at LeTourneau University and 21 at Baylor University) were involved in this senior design project during the grant period. They were educated about the medical diagnostics field and biosensing technology. They were able to gain valuable engineering experience by applying their skills to build a portable biodetection system. This grant is also used in part to develop and continuously offer 'Intro to Microfab' course. A total of 28 undergraduate and graduate engineering students (18 at LeTourneau University and 10 at Baylor University) took this course and received training on microfabrication tools and processes. The outcomes of this research project were shared in local and technical communities through presentations and journal publications.
